title: The $100k question facing Nic Maddinson
text:
Nic Maddinson is one of 30 Australians going into Monday’s Indian Premier League auction February 16, 2017 1:51pm by Joe Barton Source: FOX SPORTS AS Nic Maddinson edges closer to a return to cricket, the dumped Test batsman could face a $100,000 question on Monday in what shapes as the most interesting storyline to emerge from the IPL auction. 
The 25-year-old is on a self-imposed break from cricket, missing NSW’s past two Sheffield Shield games, but is one of 30 Australians set to go under the hammer at the auction in Bangalore. 
With a modest reserve price of $97,000 and an extensive history in Twenty20 cricket, mostly for the Sydney Sixers, Maddinson could loom as a handy pickup for a team looking for squad depth. 
And should he be picked up, we may soon know more about his immediate plans when it comes to cricket. 
There is no set timeframe for Maddinson’s return to the Sheffield Shield — and no guarantee it will even be this season — but there were encouraging signs this week that he is on the right path. 
Maddinson was set to train with the non-Shield playing members of the NSW at Drummoyne Oval this week, only for rain to intervene. 
Could that be enough to convince an IPL team to take a punt on him? We will find out on Monday. 
The IPL season is still more than two months away, and it could be a good place to regain some confidence away from the spotlight in Australia — although his record in India (with 20 runs at 6.66 from just three IPL performances) may be the bigger deterrent. Brad Haddin is in form and chasing a big IPL deal. Source: AAP 
HADDIN HUNTING FOR A PAY DAY 
There were more than a few raised eyebrows and a chuckles in Mumbai when Brad Haddin set his reserve price at nearly $300k — the second-highest band. 
Honestly, you could almost hear the sniggers all the way from Sydney. 
And yes, the former Test wicketkeeper is 39 years old. 
But is it that outrageous for a team to have a look in his direction? 
Haddin is still one of the cleanest strikers of a ball there is — his straight drive remains one of the most aesthetically pleasing in world cricket — and he’s certainly capable of producing a matchwinning innings. 
You need look no further than his outstanding 73 off 39 balls in the opening match of the Pakistan Super League, when he smoked three sixes and eight fours to propel Islamabad to victory a week ago. 
With experience on the subcontinent, and a strike rate that typically hovers at the impressive 140 mark, Haddin has proven he not finished yet by any means. Pat Cummins and Mitchell Johnson (foreground) have set the highest reserve prices. Source: News Corp Australia 
FEARSOME FAST BOWLERS 
The two biggest Australian names to throw their hats into the ring are lightning fast quicks Mitchell Johnson and Pat Cummins. 
Both have a bit to prove, but even with a reserve price of $389,000 it’s fair to say there’ll be a bit of interest. 
Johnson was cut by the Kings XI Punjab after a disappointing season which left some wondering whether his cricket career was wrapping up. 
But the Ashes hero looked a million bucks again after a rejuvenating Big Bash League, where he pulled out some extraordinary performances to spearhead Perth Scorchers to a record third title. 
That 3-3 which demolished the Melbourne Stars? That probably turned a few heads and had most franchises moving pieces around trying to make room. 
Cummins on the other hand has barely had a taste of the IPL as injuries have kept him sidelined most of the time but — touch wood — he looks healthy and is back bowling fire. 
Throw in the vastly improved batting which he displayed at times for the Thunder this year, and Cummins becomes a valuable piece for teams that want to bowl heat and bat deep. Ben McDermott produced one of the knocks of the BBL. Source: AAP 
THE BARGAINS 
OK, not everyone can earn the mega bucks of Shane Watson, Virat Kohli and MS Dhoni. 
But there’s bargains to be had amongst the Australian offerings — particularly in the form of the game’s rising stars. 
Rising T20 specialist Chris Green — currently plying his trade in the PSL for the Lahore Qalandars — and fellow young all-rounder Ashton Turner are both listed at the second-lowest reserve price of $39,000. 
Want cheaper? No worries. 
Ben McDermott became an overnight sensation in the Big Bash when he blazed an extraordinary century for Hobart to help reel in the biggest score in BBL history against Melbourne Renegades. 
His ridiculous 114 off 52 balls set up the last-ball win as the Hurricanes notched 8-223 — if anyone in India was watching, he should get a nibble because at the lowest reserve of $19,000 they won’t come cheaper. 
Hurricanes teammate D’Arcy Short, also listed at the lowest base price, is a punishing top-order batsman and a more than-handy left-arm spinner — as the late bloomer showed in Wednesday night’s PMs XI match where he went within a whisker of snaring a hat-trick. 
THE FULL LIST OF AUSSIE HOPEFULS 
$389,000 reserve
